awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Delivery systems for the controlled release of bioactive compounds to extend the shelf life of perishable agricultural products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce the loss of fresh produce due to microbial spoilage during its journey from farm to consumer. These food losses amount to $200 billion per year in direct costs worldwide, as well as an increase the environmental footprint of food production systems.  The food spoilage also causes additional potential damage to the environment and human health due to the increased use of synthetic pesticides and preservatives in an effort to prevent loss. This project aims to reduce food spoilage and the unintended consequences by providing safe, effective, and environmentally responsible methods for managing food crops post-harvest.

The proposed project focuses on the development of controlled release systems to deliver naturally occurring, safe, anti-fungal essential oil compound (EOC) vapors to protect perishable agricultural produce from spoilage. Several experimental systems have been reported in the literature for the controlled release delivery of the EO vapors but no commercialized solutions yet exist. This highlights the importance of focused research and development needed to develop these EO delivery systems. Concurrently with controlled release systems investigations, crucial testing and modeling capabilities both in house and in an external network are also being developed. These include various volatile quantitation techniques ranging from photoionization detectors (PIDs) to gas chromatography with mass spectroscopy (GC-MS) instruments, test beds, and dynamic and finite element modeling of transport phenomena.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ryp Labs has developed a technology for the controlled release of volatile organic compounds which extend the shelf life of fresh fruit and vegetables. A core component of the technology is the matrix which contains the volatile organic compounds and controls the release rate of the compounds which act via the vapor phase to extend the shelf life of fruits and vegetables. At the onset of Phase I Ryp Labs had already developed a controlled-release matrix material platform. However, while this material is a suitable matrix in many cases, additional active compounds, use cases, and marketing requirements could be addressed with the development of other improved matrix materials for the control-release system. Therefore, the goal of Phase I was to develop and characterize 2-3 other alternative controlled-release matrix materials. The methods used were literature review, controlled-release performance and stability measurements, and integration of these learnings into improved prototypes. 


The first work package involved defining criteria to evaluate potential matrix materials and conducting a literature review of candidate materials, with a deliverable of an internal report summarizing the findings. The criteria were derived from regulatory, marketing, manufacturing, and efficacy requirements. Three of the most promising controlled-release matrix materials were chosen for investigation.


After selection of the candidate materials, the methods required to characterize their controlled-release properties were developed. The methods included evaluation of the matrix capacity, equilibrium vapor pressure, and release rate for each active compound. Each class of materials’ controlled-release properties were measured and the pros and cons of each were summarized.


Next the stability and shelf-life of each candidate matrix material was assessed, both in storage and during use. Typical use cases, as prescribed by the environments in which produce are stored, involve fridge or room temperatures and high relative humidity. Each class of materials’ stability in these conditions was measured. Storage conditions that maximize these materials’ shelf lives were identified and validated. The testing method development and validation of storage stability was a crucial milestone, as Ryp Labs now has a shelf stable prototype that can be shipped to future customers with the confidence that the performance will be the same as measured in house.


The last work package of Phase I involved integrating the learnings into new, improved proof of concept prototypes. First, a prototype was developed based on a combination of two controlled release matrices . By combining these materials, the capacity of the prototype was increased while achieving the target release profiles and stability to humidity. However, the shelf stability of the prototype was limited.


We plan to further develop this platform architecture in Phase II to a mature level that can be readily used in various product designs. The focus will be on developing and expanding the technical capability envelope to enable  engineering products with different capacity and release profile requirements. This in turn will  make it possible to access a broader range of use cases.


In summary, the work performed under this grant has provided Ryp Labs with a strong foundation for further development, and an early understanding of the performance envelopes of each of the materials investigated. This is crucial information for developing new prototypes for specific use cases from this controlled-release technology platform. Learnings from Phase I already led to the development of a first round of product prototypes with improved formulation, performance, cost, and stability to move us towards gaining commercial traction. We expect to achieve a much stronger and more robust technology and product platform in Phase II , which will enable the next iteration of Ryp Labs products that can be applied in a wider set of use cases.


Last Modified: 05/22/2023
Modified by: Benjamin G Jones
